eclair.review:
the vanilla is good. the chocolate is good. the pumpkin... eh... not so good.

back home (hong kong), the custard is really really chilled so it really is a treat. here, its room temperature which kinda makes it less appealing. 

so I cheat. I buy empty eclair shells and stuff them with ice cream when I get home. 

my mama says don't eat here or you'll really start to look round and jolly like the papa on the logo....  my mama's always right

excerpts: I had a chocolate filled creme puff and a vanilla cream filled eclair and both were phenominal.
The fillings here are some of the best I've ever had.
I do wish they fried the dough so it would be flakier, but it's a minor complaint.
The only thing keeping me form giving this place a 5 star is the prices.
$2.25 for each creme puff is pretty expensive.
That's not going to stop me from coming back though.
eclair.author: Byron C.
eclair.review: Despite it's many locations, I've never been to a beard papas until last week. I had a chocolate filled creme puff and a vanilla cream filled eclair and both were phenominal. The fillings here are some of the best I've ever had. I do wish they fried the dough so it would be flakier, but it's a minor complaint. The only thing keeping me form giving this place a 5 star is the prices. $2.25 for each creme puff is pretty expensive. That's not going to stop me from coming back though.

excerpts: The eclair with vanilla cream filling.
Buy 10 dozen if you are a fatty or just buy 1 or 2 if you are not a fatty.
eclair.author: Fatty A.
eclair.review: Since this is a Japanese founded establishment I am almost afraid to ask how they really came up with the name Beard Papa.  I am sure it was probably related to the "cream filling."  Aside from the man juice name, in order to continue to be fat like me you only need to order one cream puff here.  The eclair with vanilla cream filling.  Buy 10 dozen if you are a fatty or just buy 1 or 2 if you are not a fatty.

excerpts: But anyway, I walked in and ordered myself a chocolate eclair, or excuse me, a double chocolate eclair.
I waited until I got home to eat it, and for the love of me, I passed out from a sugar induced coma.
Long story short: It was GOOD.
Tasty, and the filling inside ...
I can't describe it.
It had a nice texture, went down smooth.
Service was okay ... for maybe two minutes, the way they were talking to each other made it seem like they didn't know what an eclair was.
Like it was such a travesty that someone didn't order their world famous holier-than-thou cream puff.
eclair.author: Caroline L.
eclair.review:
Okay, so I usually hate when some new "trend" arrives and all of a sudden everyone and their mom is saying how good something is. But then I hate it even more when I actually LIKE the new trend, and this being going to Beard Papa's to get a fattening snack. I always pass it by while walking to Whole Foods (go fig) and for some reason yesterday I decided to go in and try it. I was standing outside looking at the menu, just to see if it would burn a hole in my pocket (or if I thought it was worth it), and some lady dressed in rags told me to "Go in. It's good." I'm like ... okay, if the lady in rags says it's good, maybe it IS good (or maybe she just wanted to talk to me). But anyway, I walked in and ordered myself a chocolate eclair, or excuse me, a double chocolate eclair. I waited until I got home to eat it, and for the love of me, I passed out from a sugar induced coma. Long story short: It was GOOD. Tasty, and the filling inside ... I can't describe it. It had a nice texture, went down smooth. Service was okay ... for maybe two minutes, the way they were talking to each other made it seem like they didn't know what an eclair was. Like it was such a travesty that someone didn't order their world famous holier-than-thou cream puff. Pfffffttt.

I don't know how the cream puff tastes though, and I don't care to know. I hate cream puffs.

excerpts: they also have an eclair (chocolate glazed version of the cream puff) and some kind of molten chocolate lava cake that i haven't yet tried.
eclair.author: Clara K.
eclair.review:
i first tried beard papa cream puffs in nyc a few years ago, and was ecstatic when they opened a store at this location on yerba buena lane in san francisco. after a few visits, my elation slipped half a notch, but not because the cream puffs aren't excellent -- they're still quite tasty with the crisp outer shell that they fill with creamy custard when you order -- but because i think i've just kinda outgrown them or maybe realized that only occasional indulgence is a good thing and getting sick of beard papa's CAN happen. :P or maybe because i tried the chocolate one and it wasn't that good, weakly flavored and a bit grainy. i do wholeheartedly recommend the original vanilla flavor, as well as the pumpkin flavor and the strawberry. the green tea is good if you're a green tea fan, and caramel tastes like vanilla with a hint of caramel (which is good but not that caramelly). i also recently tried the royal milk tea flavor and it was okay, but not one of the better flavors. come to think of it, i guess i've tried pretty much all their flavors! the only thing is that they have vanilla and chocolate every day, but the rest of the flavors rotate on a weekly basis so they might not have the flavor you want the day you go.

i've also tried the cheesecake stick which wasn't very good. they also have an eclair (chocolate glazed version of the cream puff) and some kind of molten chocolate lava cake that i haven't yet tried.

i didn't know i had so much to say about beard papa's. the sad thing is that i could go on, but i won't. :P

excerpts: I've had the eclair, which is basically a vanilla cream puff with chocolate magic shell squirted on it.
The chocolate shell added another level of texture to the puff and cream layers that didn't really work for me.
The two flavors of the week (milk tea and caramel)
I've had are pretty good, but they aren't the reason why I keep going back.
eclair.author: mandy f.
eclair.review: I'd consider myself a fan of Beard Papa's cream puffs...just not a loyal enough fan to wait longer than 10 minutes for them.  Luckily,  I've never had to wait longer than that.  My favorite is the classic vanilla bean.  I've had the eclair, which is basically a vanilla cream puff with chocolate magic shell squirted on it.  The chocolate shell added another level of texture to the puff and cream layers that didn't really work for me.  The two flavors of the week (milk tea and caramel) I've had are pretty good, but they aren't the reason why I keep going back.

excerpts: They only have 3 flavors: vanilla, chocolate and the eclair (which is just a vanilla puff covered in chocolate).
eclair.author: Judy L.
eclair.review: These puffs are giagantor! The cream in the puff is more like a pudding consistency that isn't too heavy. They only have 3 flavors: vanilla, chocolate and the eclair (which is just a vanilla puff covered in chocolate). I went online to find out that other Beard Papa's have green tea and earl grey tea cream custard flavors. Only if these flavors would also come to SF for a limited time! Just make certain to eat them fresh or the puff gets soggy.

excerpts: I had a tough time deciding on eclair or vanilla puff.
eclair.author: Colleen B.
eclair.review: Stumbled across Beard Papa today, recalling all the hype I decided to try these so well marketed puffs. It was a bit after noon so most the office worker types were eating something substantial, I had a killer hangover so sugar was in order. I had a tough time deciding on eclair or vanilla puff. I'm a simple gal so opted for the latter, tho my interest was peaked by the green tea and pumpkin flavors it just didn't seem right to eat custards of that ilk. There was a few folks in 'line', because the staff, while friendly, are overly cautious. This gave me time to decide without freaking out and second guessing my choice. I found the little puff just delightful and am sure I will visit again when I need a fix.

excerpts: I had an eclair and she tried the stawberry cream puff.
Both were okay
, we were expecting more because of all the hype.
The french roast coffee and service was good.
I would not come back for cream puffs.
eclair.author: Lorraine B.
eclair.review: Me and my friend came here after the football game yesterday and it was okay. The cream puffs actually have custard in them not whipped cream. I had an eclair and she tried the stawberry cream puff. Both were okay, we were expecting more because of all the hype. The french roast coffee and service was good. I would not come back for cream puffs.

excerpts: My boyfriend had the double chocolate eclair which was oozing with chocolate, it was pretty good.
The location was interesting, next door to St. Patrick's church, what a great combo!
eclair.author: Carmen M.
eclair.review: This was a yummy experience!  Licking off the chocolate from my boyfriend's mouth and eating the strawberry puff was really fun!  We waited in line for about 45 minutes. By the time we arrived at the front cashier, we were suckered into buying the 6 pieces of goodies.   You can mix and match the pieces too.  My boyfriend had the double chocolate eclair which was oozing with chocolate, it was pretty good.  The location was interesting, next door to St. Patrick's church, what a great combo!

excerpts: The combination is two eclair-like shells filled with a whopping amount of sweet cream, NOT eclair custard like at Beard Papa's.
My Papa cream puff was good, but it felt more like an eclair to me and in my tainted world of dairy and cows, you just don't mess with the undisputed champion of cream puffs.
From now on Beard Papa's only sells eclairs to me.
eclair.author: Taylor P.
eclair.review: When I finally decided to venture to Beard Papa's, the lines and craziness eventually died down. This would not have been the second time that a pastry has caused such a panic in the world. Four years ago, a Krispy Kreme opened up in suburban Milwaukee drawing thousands to the small parking lot. Police were called in to direct traffic and news choppers hovered over the newly constructed store to snap photos of all the hype. Kenny Rogers, in town for a concert, showed up to pledge his love for the donut. Which leads me to exclaim that after eating my first Beard Papa, I had to think that the tasty treat was not the best cream puff I ever had. Krispy Kreme may have made Milwaukeeans look like a bunch of hype-driven consumers, but Wisconsin does lay claim to one title, even a chain store cannot topple; best cream puff in the World. Each year during the Wisconsin State Fair, nearly 360,000 puffs are sold, an average of 57 per minute. They have been crafting this treat for nearly 85 years and it is hard to beat. The combination is two eclair-like shells filled with a whopping amount of sweet cream, NOT eclair custard like at Beard Papa's. My Papa cream puff was good, but it felt more like an eclair to me and in my tainted world of dairy and cows, you just don't mess with the undisputed champion of cream puffs. From now on Beard Papa's only sells eclairs to me.

excerpts: eclair.
or plain.
i get the eclair cause well, its covered in chocolate yo!
my favorite is the eclair with the pumpkin filling.
it felt like i ate halloween the first time i tried it.
several children were crying over the loss of their favorite holiday.
fear not citizens!
it just TASTES like halloween!
eclair.author: Spencer P.
eclair.review:
ill call beard papas my DADDY any effin day o' the WEEK.
allright. its just cream puffs you may say. whats so special? WELL ILL TELL YOU. these cream puffs are the size of 16 year old football prodigy's fists! ok. now lets get to some more refined details.
you get three styles o' puff. cookie crumb or something. eclair. or plain. i get the eclair cause well, its covered in chocolate yo!
there are typically three flavors of filling: vanilla, chocolate, or the flavor of the week. ive had em all and betterbelieveit that all are good. 
my favorite is the eclair with the pumpkin filling. it felt like i ate halloween the first time i tried it. several children were crying over the loss of their favorite holiday. fear not citizens! it just TASTES like halloween! 
oh and the chocolate fondant cake is delish. small and SuPeR rich chocolate snack. be sure to have 4 napkins at the ready.
nice location. simple set up. friendly staff.
takes about 10 seconds to get your puff. trust me in that you will want to buy another but really now...do you need all that cream and puff at 9 in the morning? 
hellyesyoudo.
eat here. support it. cream puffs are waves of the future.
and macaroons. but thats for a different yelp.
puff away, sf.

excerpts: To top things off, I'd definitely go with an eclair if I'm in the mood to indulge (which I always do).
The eclair is basically a cream puff covered with chocolate.
Must I say, this is DELICIOUS.
eclair.author: Fanny C.
eclair.review: I happened upon this place when I was walking back towards downtown after having dinner at Thirsty Bear with a friend. The smell of this place drew me in and has had me since then. I've tried their daily special cream puffs, but the original and chocolate cream puffs are still the best. To top things off, I'd definitely go with an eclair if I'm in the mood to indulge (which I always do). The eclair is basically a cream puff covered with chocolate. Must I say, this is DELICIOUS. The cheese sticks aren't too impressive, but still not bad if you're in the mood (but then I'd just go to the cheesecake factory which is just a couple blocks away). The chocolate lava cake is absolutely SCRUMPTIOUS. They would ask you if you want to eat it right away, or would like to bring it home. If you'd like to eat it right away, they would pop it into the microwave for 10 seconds and when you dive into the cake, the warm molten chocolate center oozes out in all its goodness. It's just the perfect ending to a great meal or a night in the city.

excerpts: Another is the Fondant Au Chocolate - though delicious - was also not as delicious as it could have been.
fondant au chocolate.author: Nina M.
fondant au chocolate.review:
I don't know what to say that would be different than anyone else.

Beard Papa originated from Osaka, Japan in 1999 that expanded internationally because of its popularity.

I love Beard Papa's cream puffs - green tea, vanilla, and chocolate being my top favorites.  

I would rate it 5, except I'm not a huge fan of its other products.  The cheesecake is adorable and good to eat, but not as great as the cream puff.  Another is the Fondant Au Chocolate - though delicious - was also not as delicious as it could have been.

excerpts: For mango lovers, my buddy Steph recommended me the Mango Ice Shower!
Shaved ice, mango sauce, topped with fresh mangoes.
mango ice shower.author: Mona C.
mango ice shower.review:
4.5 Stars

+ Yummy
+ Fresh Ingredients 
+ Friendly Service
+ Clean

- So Fatty :(

LOVE Beard Papas!!! Came here with 2 of my buddies while waiting for a movie to start which wasn't in another hour and half or so. There were no line when we got here. Yes!!

I've been to other Beard Papa locations, and I gotta say, this is the best one yet! There were so much to choose from but the first thing that caught my eyes were the cream puffs. The "Daily Flavors" are: Vanilla Bean and Chocolate. Weekly Flavors are: Caramel, Coffee / Tiramisu, Green Tea, Pumpkin and Strawberry. (1 for $2.25, 6 for $11.00, 12 for $22.00)

Everything looked so tasty! I  was debating on whether to try the Green Tea or the Vanilla Bean, but after a long tough decision, I've gone with the Vanilla Bean Cookie Ccrunch Puff. Sooo good. Crunchy exterior, and creamy and sweet interior. Mmm~ Kinda regret not ordering a dozen to go...

For mango lovers, my buddy Steph recommended me the Mango Ice Shower! Shaved ice, mango sauce, topped with fresh mangoes. My mouth is watering just thinking about it.

Will be back to try all the other flavors! :D

excerpts: Working in SOMA, I had passed Bear Papa many times, unable to shake the dirty feeling I got from the term "mango ice shower.
mango ice shower.author: Becca S.
mango ice shower.review:
Working in SOMA, I had passed Bear Papa many times, unable to shake the dirty feeling I got from the term "mango ice shower."  One day, inevitably, it was time to stop in and try the puffs.

Beard Papa's is definitely your standard fast-food-type joint, and I wouldn't really advocate eating there unless you're feeling particularly insouciant about ambiance. (2/3 etymologically French words, go me!)  But nobody really does that.  They grab their loot, their dirty, dirty secrets, and go.  We did the same.

I like that they have a few different varieties of puffs, you can get things like green tea and mango - but we opted just for chocolate and vanilla.  Watching them fill the pastry puffs was also fairly entrancing, perhaps indicative of the sugar coma that was to ensue.  They were tasty, to be sure.  I didn't, like, totally flip out over them, but perhaps I'm not a cream puff kinda gal.  Maybe I should go back...

excerpts: Other locations offer mango ice shower, mochi, and Mont Blanc.
mango ice shower.author: Aileen A.
mango ice shower.review:
Best Chocolate Eclair (with Vanilla filling) I've ever eaten. However, that's if you wait 5-10 minutes for it to "thaw" out a little. I got it a little cold, didn't get it fresh from the oven. They should seriously consider changing the fridge temperature or think about making less puffs so that there's not a lot of excess to chill up. 

Despite that, the eclair was delicious!

Cream puffs were just okay, puff too crunchy (tasted like crackers for a sec)-not flakey like most-but super generous with the filling.

They offer  3 types of cream filling (green tea, vanilla, chocolate) in the puffs or eclairs. I only realized this when the cashier asked. I'm not sure I saw these choices on the menu.

Other desserts they offer are cheesecake sticks-if you're on the go and don't want cream filling dripping all over, and chocolate au fondant. Other locations offer mango ice shower, mochi, and Mont Blanc. 

For beverages: tea, coffee, vitamin water (no formula fiddy though!), etc. I wish they had some iced mocha-chocolate frappes to go down with my eclairs...

Not worth the travel, but worth the two block walk if you happen to be around the neighborhood...

excerpts: They also have some other Japanese crafted pastries such as Japanese cheesecake to choose from.
cheesecake.author: Janice K.
cheesecake.review:
Double Matcha, Chocolate and Vanilla, Double Chocolate, Butter Honey Vanilla, Butter Honey Matcha, or Butter Honey Chocolate. So many options in puff and filling! 

Here's the breakdown of this cream puff goodness: 

Puff choices: 
1) Original
2) Chocolate glazed
3) Honey butter glazed
4) Matcha glazed

Cream filling: 
1) Vanilla
2) Chocolate
3) Matcha

You can fill your cream heart with whatever combination of the above! 
They also have some other Japanese crafted pastries such as Japanese cheesecake to choose from. 

I purchased a box of 9 the day before Thanksgiving to bring over to a party (knowing that everything would be closed on Thanksgiving day) and kept it in the fridge overnight. Although the exterior of the puff wasn't freshly crisp the next day, it wasn't wasn't soggy either! A day in the fridge and the puffs retained their shape, flavor and almost entirety of its texture. 

I was told the Beard Papas in the USA are made in a peanut free factory and this is different than the Beard Papas in Asia where this isn't the case. Don't quote me on that, but if true, this is exciting for my peanut allergy yelpers!

Eat here!

excerpts: and the hubby got the original filled with vanilla and a cheesecake stick on the side.
The cream puffs are soft enough and filled with a delicious cream with flecks of vanilla bean.
Try it next time you're in the area.
cheesecake.author: Tammie W.
cheesecake.review:
This place was recommended by a friend who said we should get 6 to share.  Uh...these are big ass cream puffs and one per person is sufficient!

This location had the original, crunch  and the chocolate cream puff.  You then choose a filling and have the option to choose between vanilla, caramel and chocolate.  These are enormous cream puffs and not the baby ones you see at Costco.  They run between $2.70-$3.50 per cream puff but are a delightful treat   

I had the crunch filled with vanilla and the hubby got the original filled with vanilla and a cheesecake stick on the side.  The cream puffs are soft enough and filled with a delicious cream with flecks of vanilla bean.   Try it next time you're in the area.

excerpts: Anyway I ordered an extra puff to have a total of 4 puffs and 2 cheesecake for a box.
The guy doesn't know how to put the cheesecakes in the box without "squishing" them.
Lol I fixed it for him but the cheesecakes were kind of messed up from him touching them :/ totally not presentable as a gift.
cheesecake.author: Grace Z.
cheesecake.review:
I love the cream puff however this review is for the service. They need to improve on customer service especially the guy who package them. Very sloppy. To get a box apparently I have been told different things each time. One visit I had to order 6 puffs to get a box, but this time I was told 4. I ordered 3 puffs and 2 cheesecakes and the guy puts them in 2 bags. I wish they would ask at the register if I would like a box for an extra one dollar. I'm not going to carry around 2 shitty little bags of puffs and cheesecakes. They barely even fit 3 puffs in one!
Anyway I ordered an extra puff to have a total of 4 puffs and 2 cheesecake for a box. The guy doesn't know how to put the cheesecakes in the box without "squishing" them. 
Lol I fixed it for him but the cheesecakes were kind of messed up from him touching them :/ totally not presentable as a gift.

excerpts: Went back and had the creme brûlée cream puff and the original cream with vanilla filling, also a cheesecake.
I'm glad we went back to give it another try.
We enjoyed every one of them
cheesecake.author: Reis L.
cheesecake.review: Went back and had the creme brûlée cream puff and the original cream with vanilla filling, also a cheesecake.I'm glad we went back to give it another try. We enjoyed every one of them

excerpts: Everything I have ever tried from cream puffs, eclairs, cheesecake sticks to chocolate lava cakes are delicious.
Customer service however is non existent.
Me and my coworkers were served by this extremely rude lady who was a BITCH.
She was very unfriendly, didn't want to answer questions, no thank you.
She basically acted like we were a nuisance by making our purchases.
She completely ruined our experience.
I will take my business elsewhere if I see her again.
There's another Beard Papa close by inside Westfield Mall.
cheesecake.author: Nerdy P.
cheesecake.review: The goodies here are solid 5-star quality. Everything I have ever tried from cream puffs, eclairs, cheesecake sticks to chocolate lava cakes are delicious. Customer service however is non existent. Me and my coworkers were served by this extremely rude lady who was a BITCH. She was very unfriendly, didn't want to answer questions, no thank you. She basically acted like we were a nuisance by making our purchases. She completely ruined our experience. I will take my business elsewhere if I see her again. There's another Beard Papa close by inside Westfield Mall.

excerpts: I did see cheesecake sticks but honestly after a subpar eclair I couldn't bring myself to continue.
cheesecake.author: Breanna P.
cheesecake.review:
These cream puffs are made fresh daily but still are not up to par. This sounds really rude but honestly I think I've had better at Whole Foods. I hate comparing businesses but I don't mess around when it comes to dessert! 

I admit, I ordered an eclair but let me tell you... It tasted exactly like a cream puff. They are definitely not suppose to taste the same. The cream filling was too fluffy and not dense enough. The only difference between the two are that the "eclair" had chocolate on its shell. 

They are in a great location that is a prime touristy spot. Maybe that's all that's going for them? I did see cheesecake sticks but honestly after a subpar eclair I couldn't bring myself to continue. 

Dessert is my favorite type of indulgence. I don't mess around when it comes to that portion of the menu. I was really disappointed in the turnout. I thought I might have been too harsh so I had two friends also taste it. They reassured me that I'm not a psycho eclair critic and that it was a less than average eating experience.

excerpts: I was torn - the recommended vanilla puff, or the cheesecake stick?
I went with the vanilla puff, which was good but had a few crunchy spots (I've made cream puffs, so
I know it's not tough to have consistently soft puffs).
The problem is that as you bite, if the puff doesn't cooperate - you get little puff and cream out the sides which is annoying.
I had been around long enough to get a cheesecake stick.
What regret!
cheesecake.author: Melinda K.
cheesecake.review:
I was so excited this place was on the corner of my hotel. I was torn - had dinner in an hour but had never seen a cream puff place, so I had to sacrifice part of my delicious burger to make room for this. I was torn - the recommended vanilla puff, or the cheesecake stick? I went with the vanilla puff, which was good but had a few crunchy spots (I've made cream puffs, so I know it's not tough to have consistently soft puffs). The problem is that as you bite, if the puff doesn't cooperate - you get little puff and cream out the sides which is annoying. Their vanilla cream is solid but I wish it had just a little more vanilla-ness.

But I am pretty sure if I lived in the area, that this would be a solid contender when I needed a snack/sweet-fix. It's about the price of the designer donuts that are popular on the east coast, where I'm from. I *WISH* I had been around long enough to get a cheesecake stick. What regret!

excerpts: I decided to get the cheesecake stick instead.
It was warm (as perhaps expected) but tasted like it had been sitting out for awhile.
Overpriced, disappointing, and stale.
On that note, everything in the window looked gross, the cream puffs.
The staff members working that day were lifeless, and the place seemed like all the energy had been sucked out of it.
Terrible experience here.
cheesecake.author: Stefanie C.
cheesecake.review: Oh man. I made the serious mistake of not getting a cream puff at Beard Papa's. I've had one before at a different location, but I just wasn't craving one this time. I decided to get the cheesecake stick instead. It was warm (as perhaps expected) but tasted like it had been sitting out for awhile. Overpriced, disappointing, and stale. On that note, everything in the window looked gross, the cream puffs. The staff members working that day were lifeless, and the place seemed like all the energy had been sucked out of it. Terrible experience here.

excerpts: The Cheesecake Sticks are also good, but at times, I sometimes I felt like I was biting into moist pound cake and not rich cheesecake.
cheesecake.author: Mark C.
cheesecake.review:
Beard Papa's delivers some awesome, decadent treats. The Cream Puffs are amazing and come in many different flavors. I haven't been disappointed with a flavor choice yet, but you can't go wrong with just getting the original flavor. The Cheesecake Sticks are also good, but at times, I sometimes I felt like I was biting into moist pound cake and not rich cheesecake. 

My waistline isn't always happy when I come to Beard Papa's, but I sure am!

excerpts: The cheesecake stick was okay and the coffee they serve smelled delicious.
cheesecake.author: Joyce D.
cheesecake.review:
I don't what it is about cream puffs, but they are so good!

Maybe it is the texture and the fluffy bread, but these cream puffs are amazing. My cousin and I decided to get a tasty treat after running the NWM 2013. Hey, we burned over 1000 calories. I think a cream puff should be okay! My favorite is the vanilla ones, but they have various flavors, like coffee! They added two new pastries instead of the original pastry. I like the location of this one because it is near the park so you can grab your snack and walk over to the outside seating at the park and people watch. The cheesecake stick was okay and the coffee they serve smelled delicious. We got a box of 6 cream puffs (2 vanilla, 2 chocolate, and 2 coffee) all were delicious. Don't worry, we didn't eat them at once, we spread it out during the day and shared with my brother!

excerpts: I also tried a cheesecake stick which was pretty good too.
cheesecake.author: Mel L.
cheesecake.review:
LOVE these puffs! I ordered some to go and they were great even the next day. But, they are the absolute best right after you pay for it and they hand you that freshly filled puff. Oooh it's so good. I got the regular vanilla and the chocolate because those are my faves. I also tried a cheesecake stick which was pretty good too. 

If you haven't tried them, I highly suggest you get over there quick. This is coming from a girl that doesn't even like cream puffs in the everyday sense. But then again, this ain't your ordinary puff.

excerpts: I also tried the cheesecake stick, it was average compared to the cream puffs.
The cheesecake was pretty creamy though.
I'd say just stick to the cream puffs.
cheesecake.author: Virginia Y.
cheesecake.review:
Green tea filling!! I thought it was a weekly special but I guess it's a daily special? I got one with a regular puff and it was dusted with green tea powder, yum. The filling has a relatively strong taste in flavor. As usual, my face gets slobbered with cream.

I also tried the cheesecake stick, it was average compared to the cream puffs. The cheesecake was pretty creamy though. I'd say just stick to the cream puffs.

excerpts: Amazing eclairs, yummy strawberry cheesecake sticks, and my personal favorite delicious cream puffs.
I've always been a fan of these.
Just the right amount of sweetness.
I don't feel guilty having two or three of these.
The only downside of this location is that they don't clean.
The table were full of crumbs and napkins and the trash was completely full.
Before we walked in, one worker was standing at the register and the other was sitting down.
We decided to eat there
and I had to wipe down the table and chairs.
cheesecake.author: Briana Nicole G.
cheesecake.review: Amazing eclairs, yummy strawberry cheesecake sticks, and my personal favorite delicious cream puffs. I've always been a fan of these. Just the right amount of sweetness. I don't feel guilty having two or three of these. The only downside of this location is that they don't clean. The table were full of crumbs and napkins and the trash was completely full. Before we walked in, one worker was standing at the register and the other was sitting down. We decided to eat there and I had to wipe down the table and chairs.

excerpts: original creams puffs and cheesecake are yum
BUT staff is unfriendly, condescending and argumentative, to think we were the only customers.
you ruined the experience for us!!
cheesecake.author: Maria L.
cheesecake.review:
original creams puffs and cheesecake are yum BUT staff is unfriendly, condescending and argumentative, to think we were the only customers. you ruined the experience for us!! sorry Beard Papa, for that you get 2 stars! 

note: typically, establishments issue a receipt, so when a customer asks for one, you issue with a smile and never argue and turn your back with a snotty smirk. why the attitude, Alex? so inappropriate and unnecessary!

excerpts: The "Cheese cake stick" (regular, strawberry and tiramisu) is another disappointing item, it's a small layer of cheesecake sliced into strips.
cheesecake.author: Luis C.
cheesecake.review:
It's amusing to me how some bored workers like to talk in another language in front of customers, thinking that nobody can understand what they are saying. She was complaining in Spanish to her 2 co-workers that I was taking too long to order. It wasn't even 5 seconds, Sheez! and I was her only customer at the time too.

Normally bakeries/ pastry shops that sell sweet products, hire cheerful people to match the food they sell. The manager of this branch didn't get that memo. The employees looked unhappy, with a deadpan, monotone voice and blank facial expressions, like if either they were inside a jail or they thought that they're too cool to work in that job, not sure. Definitely a disincentive to buy more stuff.

I just came here to try the new mini-croissants, available in 3 flavors: butter (regular), chocolate and cheese (cream cheese). Sold by 3 for $2.95/$3.45, 1/2 dozen for $5.25/$6.25, or one dozen for $10/$12. I bought a mix to try every flavor. The "Petit-cro" looked nice and tasted okay, but the inside is a little dry. Perhaps better when eaten while sipping on a cup of hot coffee or tea. http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/fO4nmPfUwyyzLDRxOIwuVg/l

The "Fondant au chocolat" are little cupcake size chocolate cakes filled with chocolate that melts after they warm it in a microwave. Nothing to rave about. If u still want something similar, go to TJ's instead for a cheaper version in the frozen foods aisle. The "Cheese cake stick" (regular, strawberry and tiramisu) is another disappointing item, it's a small layer of cheesecake sliced into strips. I'd rather have a slice of dense NY-style or Zanze's light cheesecakes instead.

I'm not a fan of the cream puffs at this store (maybe I got poorly made ones, don't know), although I really liked the ones I tried at Beard Papa's in Waikiki, inside the Food Pantry market. Also I don't know why the Cupertino location has lower prices than the SF store.

excerpts:
About 3 for each cream puff, and 2 for each cheesecake stick.

The cheesecake sticks were small and didn't leave a big impression on me.
cheesecake.author: Kevin T.
cheesecake.review:
Overall Impression: Came in with a sweet tooth, came out slightly disappointed.

Cost: About 3 for each cream puff, and 2 for each cheesecake stick.

Taste: This is a personal opinion, but I thought the cream puffs were mediocre at best. I had the green tea and vanilla cream puffs. Both had a good consistency that outdoes anything that you could buy at Costco, yet the flavor within the fillings were pretty bland. The cheesecake sticks were small and didn't leave a big impression on me. 

Customer Service: It seems like the cashiers were having a long day. They seemed to be in a rush irregardless of the fact that I was the only person in line.

Ambience/Atmosphere: A nice setting to have desserts, even though it didn't satisfy my sweet tooth.

excerpts: The cheesecake sticks are also a delicious treat but compared to the cream puffs, I think are a little small for the price.
cheesecake.author: Cece E.
cheesecake.review:
The puffs went poof and disappeared almost as soon as we got them into our greedy hands. Favorite flavors include green tea, chocolate, strawberries & cream, dulce de leche and pumpkin. The cheesecake sticks are also a delicious treat but compared to the cream puffs, I think are a little small for the price.

Right across the street from the Metreon. We usually stop by before or after a movie. We usually buy a few to eat while sitting on the lawn of Yerba Buena Gardens and enjoy their summer concerts.

excerpts: As amazing as the cream puffs sounded and looked, I actually went with one of their cheesecake sticks.
Tasty, only $2, light, and yummy.
Perfect little sugar craving satisfier!
I was a bit surprised however, how pricey the cream puffs were.
I've purchased delicious cream puffs elsewhere in the past
but these were a bit more pricey.
I will have to come back and try one next time because if they are as tasty as they sound, those few more bucks could be well worth it.
I'll be back!
cheesecake.author: Akvile D.
cheesecake.review:
Cream Puff specialty shop? WOW..brilliant and amazing at the same time!

I have a huge sweet tooth and was totally having a case of the sugar cravings while strolling around town last week when I stumbled upon this little spot. I couldn't help but go inside and see if it was true...a whole place dedicated to cream puffs and some other delicious treats!

I stopped in, the menu is simple yet fully packed of delicious sounding goodies, and the staff is friendly. I am a big fan of places that greet customers and have a smile when you approach the counter. As amazing as the cream puffs sounded and looked, I actually went with one of their cheesecake sticks. Tasty, only $2, light, and yummy. Perfect little sugar craving satisfier! I was a bit surprised however, how pricey the cream puffs were. I've purchased delicious cream puffs elsewhere in the past but these were a bit more pricey. I will have to come back and try one next time because if they are as tasty as they sound, those few more bucks could be well worth it. I'll be back! :)

excerpts: I've tried their coffee, cheesecake, and chocolate cake, but I don't recommend them.
Stick to the cream puffs!
cheesecake.author: Alice J.
cheesecake.review:
These cream puffs are great. The shell is nice and crunchy and dusted with powdered sugar. It's not too thick either so you taste a good amount of filling. I've tried all the flavors but my favorite is hands down the vanilla.

I've tried their coffee, cheesecake, and chocolate cake, but I don't recommend them. Stick to the cream puffs!

excerpts: They also sell "sticks" of cheesecake.
Picture a slightly skinner stick of butter, but made of cheesecake -- not butter.
It would be more cool if it was cheesecake on a stick.
If you offer this, please send me royalty checks.
cheesecake.author: Sunny T.
cheesecake.review:
2.25 stars to be generous b/c that's the price of a cream puff.

I really wanted to like Beard Papa. It made me think of Papa Smurf... but I didn't like the cream puffs as much as I like the 1980s little blue cartoons. 

* FAB location next to Schoggi chocolates of Switzerland... and nice clean design, like a factory tour: video of how cream puffs are made and clear glass, so you can see the workers make your order. Chocolate and regular puffs sit on trays; the drill pump device injects cream into the puff.

* BEST aroma -- baked goody smell. Cool concept: vanilla, chocolate, or the cream flavor of the week (changed on Fridays). At the beginning of the week, I got a reg. puff with green tea filling... the puff was dusted with green tea powdered sugar too. OK taste, not too sweet -- but not addictive as other Yelpers make it seem.

* I visited on a second occasion to test consistency of the quality. Customer service was lacking both times. If workers are not pleasant, it dampens my enthusiasm for your treats. 

** BTW when you saw that I was NOT HAPPY (but DISAPPOINTED) with my order (b/c you didn't read it back to me and I got something different than what I intended -- and I didn't even bite into the puff) you SHOULD HAVE offered me what I wanted: a baked chocolate puff filled with coffee cream, the flavor of the week. 

What I got: a regular puff with chocolate cream filling. 

Note: There's a Beard Papa's in the food court of the Westfield San Francisco center at 5th Street and Market... but the mall setting really cramps the magical factory feeling. They sell the same widgets anyway.

They also sell "sticks" of cheesecake. Picture a slightly skinner stick of butter, but made of cheesecake -- not butter. It would be more cool if it was cheesecake on a stick. If you offer this, please send me royalty checks.

excerpts: The cheesecake and tiramisu sticks here are omg good too!
cheesecake.author: Angela K.
cheesecake.review:
I love the green tea and the strawberry puffs!! 

Vanilla are always a safe bet though, especially if its your first time. 

I like this location because it doesn't get as busy, it seems more clean and the staff is relatively friendly. 

The cheesecake and tiramisu sticks here are omg good too!

I've been lucky enough to go to the Beard Papa's in Shanghai and let me tell you. HOLYCRAPA;DFA;DFAFMOSTAMAZINGCREAMPUFFFLAVORS EVER. 

They have blueberry yogurt and green tea and mini ice cream filled puffs. I met up with a friend who was in Hong Kong the week before and she told me the Beard Papa's there had fresh fruit flavors! Ohhh man. Why can't they have such flavors here?!?!? WHY?!??

excerpts: I've also tried the cheesecake sticks.
A slice of cheesecake is usually a bit too heavy for me, so these sticks are the perfect size to fulfill a craving for cheesecake!
cheesecake.author: Valerie R.
cheesecake.review:
Whenever I'm hanging out around Downtown SF, I try to make a point to visit Beard Papa's!  Their cream puffs are so, so, soooo delicious! The play on textures with the crispy pastry and the velvety cream filling is such a win!combination.  Also, one cream puff is really filling, so the price, I think, is appropriate. Flavors I've tried are the vanilla, chocolate, coffee and matcha (green tea), and I really loved every single one of those, especially the matcha!

I've also tried the cheesecake sticks. A slice of cheesecake is usually a bit too heavy for me, so these sticks are the perfect size to fulfill a craving for cheesecake! They're not overly sweet, and they've got just the right amount of crust to filling.

In anycase, make sure to grab several napkins if you decide to just go for the cream puffs!! Tryin to eat a cream puff without spilling all over is an art I have yet to manage!

excerpts: Don't forget to get that "healthy" cheesecake stick and cookie crunch puff with vanilla filling.
Oh yeah and the milk too!
cheesecake.author: Betty D.
cheesecake.review:
Location is much, much calmer than the one inside the mall. So if you don't want to stand in the long lines at the food court, take a stroll to the Beard Papa's store around the block. There's chairs inside and out to sit and enjoy your puff but make sure you eat right away. A day old puff is no good...

Don't forget to get that "healthy" cheesecake stick and cookie crunch puff with vanilla filling. Oh yeah and the milk too!

excerpts: I was tickled by the other stuff there, especially the cheesecake sticks - how cute and original!
Service was quick and friendly.
The only little thing I wasn't thrilled by was the fact that they have four flavors listed as "weekly flavors"
but in fact only one of them was the flavor of the week
and this was not indicated on the menu.
There was a big round sticker next to one flavor, but it wasn't the flavor of the week, go figure.
cheesecake.author: Amanda P.
cheesecake.review:
Like others here, I had never had a cream puff, and have been wanting to try Beard Papa for I kid you not four years, but never got around to it.  Wanted a quick snack the other day so popped in here for a coffee cream puff and a cheese mini-croissant.  I think it was under $5 for both but I wasn't paying, so I don't remember for sure.

Coffee cream was very rich, but still somehow light.  For me, one was definitely enough - two would have felt gluttonous, though I bet I could have managed.  Pastry was light and not very sweet, a great complement to the cream.

Cheese in the croissant was actually a little salty and not as sweet as I was expecting - actually not really sweet at all.  It was very good though, so no complaints here.

I was tickled by the other stuff there, especially the cheesecake sticks - how cute and original!  Service was quick and friendly.  The only little thing I wasn't thrilled by was the fact that they have four flavors listed as "weekly flavors" but in fact only one of them was the flavor of the week and this was not indicated on the menu.  There was a big round sticker next to one flavor, but it wasn't the flavor of the week, go figure.

excerpts: They had tiramisu, cheesecake and strawberry.
cheesecake.author: Christina C.
cheesecake.review:
I had plenty of misgivings about Beard Papa's.   I've seen it in Southern CA but avoided it probably due to its name and logo.  I mean, its name sounds like a Smurf-themed sex shop or gay Bear bar.  I'm also not attracted to the Gordon Fisherman meets Chef Boyardee logo of an old man puffing on a pipe while I'm eating.

This Japanese-based pastry shop I guess started out in Osaka (where my mom used to live) and I love Japanese food so I figured I should give it a try.  According to their website (best watched after you've ingested said cream puffs) the original inspiration of the cream puffs came from the original Beard Papa's .... shockingly, from his facial hair.  He also seemed to be smoking while baking these "World's Best Cream Puffs".  I'm not sure what the most disturbing part of those sentences are, but I'll leave that up to you to decipher.

Regardless, the cream puffs are pretty damn amazing. I'm not normally a fan of puffed pastry seeded in custard and whipped cream, but stopping in was an unexpected treat.  I had the cookie crumb pastry with vanilla bean filling.  It was... awesome.  They also serve treats in stick form which is a form I am fond of.  They had tiramisu, cheesecake and strawberry.  They also have eclairs and chocolate fondant.  Thankfully, no beard hair or what ever Beard Papa is smoking makes its way into these delightful lessons in diabetes and obesity.

excerpts: Today I tried a strawberry mousse cheesecake strip and it was a delightful set of contrasts.
Diced bits of dark red strawberry sat next to chopped green pistachios atop a foamy sea of pale pink mousse, all resting on a bed of off-white cheesecake.
Diced bits of dark red strawberry sat next to chopped green pistachios atop a foamy sea of pale pink mousse, all resting on a bed of off-white cheesecake.
The density of the cheesecake emphasized the airiness of the mousse, while the crunch of the nuts gave a satisfying counterpoint amidst the soft, sweet joy in my mouth.

Beard Papa originated from Osaka, Japan in 1999 that expanded internationally because of its popularity.

I love Beard Papa's cream puffs - green tea, vanilla, and chocolate being my top favorites.  

I would rate it 5, except I'm not a huge fan of its other products.  The cheesecake is adorable and good to eat, but not as great as the cream puff.  Another is the Fondant Au Chocolate - though delicious - was also not as delicious as it could have been.

I didn't like the chocolate cream though because it tasted powdery to me. Maybe it was just a bad batch? The cheese cake stick was just a regular cheesecake, but not as sweet.

JONASAPPROVED!

excerpts: They have cheesecake sticks for $1.25.
It was good but not as good as a regular cheesecake.
cheesecake.review:
I walked by one day and noticed the bright yellow writing on the glass in front. I waited anxiously for opening day to come. Opening day was crazy!!! The line was out the door and down the block. They were handing out samples. I wasn't about to wait in line for that long and decided to come back when things died down a bit. 

They had a promotion going on that first week. Buy 20 cream puffs and get a free thermos. I asked about the thermos and they ran out. I was a lil' disappointed so the guy gave my girlfriend and I a charm for our cell phone. That was nice of him to do that.  

When I tasted that first puff.....oh my!!!! It was sooooo good. It wasn't too sweet. It was perfect!!!! I went back each week to taste all the other flavors. Their flavored cream puffs are "Rotating on a weekly basis". I like all of them except the chocolate one. It tasted funny to me. My favorite is green tea and milk tea. The milk tea puff is available in San Francisco only. The coffee one is available in Redwood City only. 

They have cheesecake sticks for $1.25. It was good but not as good as a regular cheesecake. 

The Fondant Au Chocolat ($2.25) is mouthwatering!!! It's not too sweet either. 

The eclairs cost a little bit more than the cream puffs. I'm not very fond of them. To me, they look exactly like a cream puff except the puff part of the eclair is more dry. And the taste is.....bleh.  This may be only me though.

They had really long lines during the day time and after work for about 6 months. After that, you can just walk in any time of day and wait in line for a few minutes. 

On their website you can see the flavors of the week for San Francisco. I've included a link below.

http://www.beardpapasf.com/flavors_sf.htm 

Go get your puff on!!!!!

EDIT 8/8/07: Just went in and saw they have gotten rid of the milk tea flavor cream puff and replaced it with tiramisu. NOOOO!!!! I really liked the milk tea one. *sob*

If it wasn't for Beard Papa's I would never ever go to that boring ass mall. The line here doesn't get horribly long b/c the workers are very efficient at this location. They got this place set up like an assembly line but then again how hard is it to fill cream puffs with the right flavor?

I'm not giving Beard Papa's 5 stars because they never have green tea cream puffs when I am there. People complain that they don't like the pudding texture of the cream but I like it just fine. cheesecake.review:
I resisted Beard Papa for a long time but have finally succumbed to its temptation.  Why?  We were a little hungry and it was too lunch for lunch, too early for Happy Hour...you know, just one of those odd hours of the day.  Then we came upon Beard Papa and it was just calling our names.  We stopped, hesitated, looked at each other and finally braved ourselves to face the demons ahead.  We looked and debated, was still debating when we got to the register...we finally ordered one puff with the flavor of the day, pumpkin.  Yes, just regular puff and not the cookie crust one and no cheesecake stick, nothing.  

We watched as the guy behind picks up a puff and filled it with the goodness we were about to taste but not before he sprinkled some powdered sugar on top.  My first bite...ooohhh...hmmmm...by now my husband is looking and wondering if he'll ever get a bite.  The pumpkin filling was delicious!  It was not sweet, very flavorful and with just the right hint of cinnamon and nutmeg...so soft, smooth and airy.  I did share and hubby agrees with me completely.  I kept asking if they sell the filling by the bottle like whipped cream and wish that they did...

My friend ordered a 6-pack and OMG, I was in love.  The cream puff was so freakin' yummy.  It was the perfect dessert after our huge lunch.

Despite that, the eclair was delicious!

Cream puffs were just okay, puff too crunchy (tasted like crackers for a sec)-not flakey like most-but super generous with the filling.

They offer  3 types of cream filling (green tea, vanilla, chocolate) in the puffs or eclairs. I only realized this when the cashier asked. I'm not sure I saw these choices on the menu.

Other desserts they offer are cheesecake sticks-if you're on the go and don't want cream filling dripping all over, and chocolate au fondant. Other locations offer mango ice shower, mochi, and Mont Blanc. 

For beverages: tea, coffee, vitamin water (no formula fiddy though!), etc. I wish they had some iced mocha-chocolate frappes to go down with my eclairs...

Not worth the travel, but worth the two block walk if you happen to be around the neighborhood...

cheesecake.author: Alexa M.
cheesecake.review:
New here to yelp and still thinking of something witty for my profile. "

First of all just want to say...yes I am addicted to Beard Papa Cream Puffs hehe.  I've enjoyed BP in Japan, Singapore, Hollywood, Gardena, and now here in the Bay Area.  My opinion is purely my opinion and everyone is entitled to their own.  I'm just here to educate and answer questions raised on previous reviews.

FYI...this is a long post and yes I have too much time on my hands =).  I base all my info on a 15min chat session with the manager of the Yerba Buena store and my personal experiences.

1) Japanese vs French Puffs
Keep in mind this is a Japanese style cream puff.  Hence the crispy shell, softer dough inside, and semi-sweet japanese Nama custard (custard and whipped cream).  I believe this is what makes the taste and texture unique.  French style puffs are softer and have a heavier, sweeter cream.  See #2 below for puff size differences.

2) Napkins required?
First of all, these puffs are big and a good amount of japanese style custard cream is purposely injected into the crispy shells.  Thus the flaky shell, amt of cream, and dusted baker's sugar leads to quite a mess.  If you saw the CNN Anderson Cooper piece on BP, the messy eating experience was one of the funny things they mentioned.  **WARNING...my opinion here** I personally feel you get quality and quantity in this pastry.  Because of the larger size puff and extra room for cream, I feel like I'm getting my money's worth and don't experience the sugar sickness afterwards because of the lighter, semi-sweet custard.  I couldn't consume french style cream in equal amounts...hmm now that I think of it maybe that's why French cream puffs are smaller. 

3) Pricey?
Some may think $1.75 for a cream puff is expensive, but personally for me and my taste...I'd rather pay for a fresh, larger-than-norm BP puff than $3 for a Satura Cream Puff (decent, but not flaky...more bread like), $1.50 for a Ranch 99 Cream Puff, or $2+ for a behind-the-glass muffin/scone/danish at my local Starbucks.  But a BP puff does go perfectly with Starbuck's dark roast.

4) Are they really fresh?
Shells are baked every 20mins and custard made every 2-3hours.  The puffs are never served hot or piping from the oven.  They need to be cooled out of the oven to get that flaky texture.  If the shells are not cooled properly or if the custard is pumped in too soon...moisture will soften the shells prematurely.  

5) Why the lines?
Going back to #4 above, the lines primarily form when patrons are left waiting for the ovens to finish baking or when the puff are still in the cooling process.  Plus add in the marketing factor here.

6) What's up with all the workers?
Every BP I've visited has had a Cream Puff line of workers so its part of the experience whether you like it or not.  Keep in mind, if they had fewer workers things might move slower.  But there is a difference between BP bakeries ambiance...I'll explain.  Have your ever been to a sushi restaurant where they greet you loudly in Japanese, proceed to shout orders, bow to you while saying Domo (sp?).  Well some BP's have this same experience where they greet/shout in Japanese which makes it more "entertaining"...purely my opinion here.  The Yerba Buena store is bland in this sense, but at least the workers are nice and courteous.    

7) Other locations?
There are two more to be open this year...Redwood City and the SF Center a block away.  Is it just me or are the two SF stores a bit close?  Why not spread them out?  In any case, living in the Peninsula myself...I'll be a regular in the Redwood City spot.  After doing a bit of research with the Yerba Buena baker, the Redwood City BP will be bigger, have more coffee house style seating, and have a barista.

8) Why only vanilla?  Where's the fondant and cheesecake fingers?
The manager I spoke to didn't really have a good answer here, but at least they finally started serving chocolate puffs this week.  As for the fondant and cheesecake fingers...good news is that  they also are baked fresh daily, bad news is that they don't start selling these sweets until a month after grand opening...bah! 

9) Who is Beard Papa?
Well its kind of an entertaining story...I suggest you walk in and ask one of the workers.

cheesecake.author: Deb K.
cheesecake.review:
At 3:30 p.m., the line was 25 people long for Beard Papa, the new cream puff shop owned by the Japanese corporation Muginoho. The San Francisco store on the new Yerba Buena Lane is one of a few U.S. franchises; the others are in New York, New Jersey, Boston, Hawaii and Los Angeles. 

After we'd waited for about 10 minutes, one of the staff came down the line, apologized, and told us it would be 30 minutes before another batch was ready. Because we were only ordering one, we decided to stay, in hopes it would be quicker. 

Beard Papa is quite the scene. Besides the long line winding out the door, there's a lot going on inside. When you first step over the threshold, you're hit with this delicious buttery scent. You can see the puffs baking in these industrial-looking, high-tech ovens. They start off the size of a hockey puck, and then rise into a much larger, 3-inch puff. The staff, dressed chef's whites, forms an assembly line when the puffs are done cooling, with one person injecting the custard into the puff, the second dusting it with powdered sugar and placing it in a bag, and the third packing them into carrying boxes.

This place inspires some kind of weird fanaticism, and after having a vanilla cream puff, I have to say it may be merited. The people in line were mostly all Asian, as were all of the staff. A family with four little boys was taking pictures with one of the staff. Overhead, on two flat screen TVs, news clips about Beard Papa played; at one point, I looked up and saw Anderson Cooper on CNN eating a cream puff. The store sells T-shirts with its mascot --- an old, bearded man in a cap, and the saying, "Who's Your Papa?" This is probably temporary, but there was a sign saying "Limit: One dozen per customer." 

The menu over the cream puff area had "Coming Soon" taped over all of the selections, except the vanilla cream puffs. Under coming soon: cream puffs of different flavors --- chocolate, caramel, green tea, pumpkin, milk tea and strawberry. With the exception of chocolate, the flavors will rotate on a weekly basis. There are also the curiously named cheesecake sticks, the fondant au chocolat and clairs. 

The puff itself is a marvel of choux pastry: flaky, buttery, and crunchy. The cream is also unique, and delicious. It is a not-too-sweet mixture of whipped cream and custard that the sign in Beard Papa's claims it takes two hours to make. You can see them scraping the vanilla bean pods, too, to extract the vanilla that flecks the cream in the vanilla cream puffs. I think this may be a new obsession for me.

cheesecake.author: Clara K.
cheesecake.review:
i first tried beard papa cream puffs in nyc a few years ago, and was ecstatic when they opened a store at this location on yerba buena lane in san francisco. after a few visits, my elation slipped half a notch, but not because the cream puffs aren't excellent -- they're still quite tasty with the crisp outer shell that they fill with creamy custard when you order -- but because i think i've just kinda outgrown them or maybe realized that only occasional indulgence is a good thing and getting sick of beard papa's CAN happen. :P or maybe because i tried the chocolate one and it wasn't that good, weakly flavored and a bit grainy. i do wholeheartedly recommend the original vanilla flavor, as well as the pumpkin flavor and the strawberry. the green tea is good if you're a green tea fan, and caramel tastes like vanilla with a hint of caramel (which is good but not that caramelly). i also recently tried the royal milk tea flavor and it was okay, but not one of the better flavors. come to think of it, i guess i've tried pretty much all their flavors! the only thing is that they have vanilla and chocolate every day, but the rest of the flavors rotate on a weekly basis so they might not have the flavor you want the day you go.

i've also tried the cheesecake stick which wasn't very good. they also have an eclair (chocolate glazed version of the cream puff) and some kind of molten chocolate lava cake that i haven't yet tried.

i didn't know i had so much to say about beard papa's. the sad thing is that i could go on, but i won't. :P

excerpts: I haven't tried their other new offerings, but am planning on going back sometime to try cheesecake and fondant au chocolat.
I hear they have mochi ice cream, but haven't seen/heard anything about them yet.
I have to say the 2 greatest selling point of Beard Papa's is that they use custard instead of cream, and it is definitely fresh.
If you're willing to spend extra for sweets, Beard Papa would be your thing.
cheesecake.author: Jessica L.
cheesecake.review:
These are really great cream puffs, but they're not as amazing as I thought they would be. But, talk about great marketing... and that custard aroma that wafts out of the cafe... enticing!
I used to eat Beard Papa's often when I was working in Asia (they're a lot cheaper there) and was thankfully a luxury I could afford but now that they've been translated into American dollars with the American price sting, I've reduced my love for Beard Papa's by a star (tear). But, when I'm in the city I 80% of the time make a stop here for two reasons: one, the menu has expanded and they have a "special" daily flavor, my favorite so far being pumpkin; two, it just smells soooo good and I always feel like I should be rewarded for my small life efforts so I'll dish out for one or two pastries. I'll buy more if I'm visiting family because they're absolute die hard fans of the original vanilla Beard Papa's cream puffs. Beyond the cream puffs and the eclairs (which are actually just the cream puffs dipped in chocolate) I haven't tried their other new offerings, but am planning on going back sometime to try cheesecake and fondant au chocolat. I hear they have mochi ice cream, but haven't seen/heard anything about them yet.
I have to say the 2 greatest selling point of Beard Papa's is that they use custard instead of cream, and it is definitely fresh. If you're willing to spend extra for sweets, Beard Papa would be your thing.

excerpts: Unfortunately I don't like their cheesecake sticks, which are pretty bland.
cheesecake.author: Michael D.
cheesecake.review: The cream puffs are highly addictive!  Made fresh, they are filled while you wait.  Chocolate and Vanilla Bean are my favorite, but there are daily flavors like Strawberry, Green Tea and Pumpkin.  They are a little expensive as a box of a dozen Cream Puffs are 22$.  They are a little over 2$ each.  Unfortunately I don't like their cheesecake sticks, which are pretty bland.  Their eclairs and chocolate cakes are ok, but the real stars are the cream puffs.  The coffee here is pretty good, the iced coffee is better.  The lines can be a little long here, so prepare to be patient.  The store is always immaculately clean.  There isn't much seating inside the store, but fortunately there's Yerba Buena Park across the street, and seating nearby infront of the Jewish Museum.  Of course outside there's plenty of pan handling to avoid and anyone sitting down enjoying a pastry is seen as an easy target.

excerpts: The cheese sticks aren't too impressive, but still not bad if you're in the mood (but then I'd just go to the cheesecake factory which is just a couple blocks away).
cheesecake.author: Fanny C.
cheesecake.review: I happened upon this place when I was walking back towards downtown after having dinner at Thirsty Bear with a friend. The smell of this place drew me in and has had me since then. I've tried their daily special cream puffs, but the original and chocolate cream puffs are still the best. To top things off, I'd definitely go with an eclair if I'm in the mood to indulge (which I always do). The eclair is basically a cream puff covered with chocolate. Must I say, this is DELICIOUS. The cheese sticks aren't too impressive, but still not bad if you're in the mood (but then I'd just go to the cheesecake factory which is just a couple blocks away). The chocolate lava cake is absolutely SCRUMPTIOUS. They would ask you if you want to eat it right away, or would like to bring it home. If you'd like to eat it right away, they would pop it into the microwave for 10 seconds and when you dive into the cake, the warm molten chocolate center oozes out in all its goodness. It's just the perfect ending to a great meal or a night in the city.

excerpts: Other locations offer mango ice shower, mochi, and Mont Blanc.
mont blanc.author: Aileen A.
mont blanc.review:
Best Chocolate Eclair (with Vanilla filling) I've ever eaten. However, that's if you wait 5-10 minutes for it to "thaw" out a little. I got it a little cold, didn't get it fresh from the oven. They should seriously consider changing the fridge temperature or think about making less puffs so that there's not a lot of excess to chill up. 

Despite that, the eclair was delicious!

Cream puffs were just okay, puff too crunchy (tasted like crackers for a sec)-not flakey like most-but super generous with the filling.

They offer  3 types of cream filling (green tea, vanilla, chocolate) in the puffs or eclairs. I only realized this when the cashier asked. I'm not sure I saw these choices on the menu.

Other desserts they offer are cheesecake sticks-if you're on the go and don't want cream filling dripping all over, and chocolate au fondant. Other locations offer mango ice shower, mochi, and Mont Blanc. 

For beverages: tea, coffee, vitamin water (no formula fiddy though!), etc. I wish they had some iced mocha-chocolate frappes to go down with my eclairs...

Not worth the travel, but worth the two block walk if you happen to be around the neighborhood...
